# 
We now describe when the“double integral” can be obtained as an "iterated"integral(Fubini!). 
Proposition.Let $S:P^{\mathrm{op}}\times P\times C^{\mathrm{op}}\times C{\longrightarrow}X$ be a functor such that theend $\int_{c}S(p,q,c,c)$ exists for all pairs $\langle p,q\rangle$ ofobjectsof $P$ ;by the parameter theorems,regard these ends as abifunctor $P^{\mathrm{op}}\times P{\longrightarrow}X$ ,and regard $s$ asabifunctor $(P\times C)^{\circ\mathbb{P}}\times(P\times C){\longrightarrow}X$ Then there is an isomorphism 
$$
\theta:\int_{\langle p,c\rangle}S(p,c,p,c)\cong\int_{p}\left[\int_{c}S(p,p,c,c)\right].
$$
Indeed,the“double end”on the left existsif andonly if the end $\int_{p}$ onthe right exists,and then thereisa unique arrow $\theta$ in $X$ suchthatthediagram 
$$
\begin{array}{l}{{\displaystyle\int_{<p,c>}S(p,p,c,c)\longrightarrow}}\ {{\qquad\theta_{\mid}^{\mid}}}\ {{\mathrm{~~}_{\psi}^{\mid}~}}\ {{\displaystyle\int_{p}\left[\int_{c}S(p,p,c,c)\right]\longrightarrow}}\ {{\qquadr}}\end{array}\nonumber
$$
commutes,wherethe horizontal arrows $\xi,\varrho$ and $\omega$ aretheuniversalwedges belonging to the corresponding ends;moreover,the arrow $\theta$ isan isomorphism. 
Proof.For each $\langle p,q\rangle\in P\times P$ we are given the end 
$$
\omega_{p,q}:\int_{c}^{}S(p,q,c,c)\xrightarrow{\omega}S(p,q,-,-).
$$
For any $x\in X$ each $P$ -indexed family $\rho_{p}:x\to\int_{c}S(p,p,c,c)$ of arrows d $X$ determines a $(P\times C)$ -indexed family $\xi_{p,c}$ as the composites 
$$
\begin{array}{r}{\xi_{p,c}:x\xrightarrow{\varrho_{p}}\int S(p,p,c,c)\xrightarrow{\omega_{p,p,c}}S(p,p,c,c);}\end{array}
$$
for $p$ fixed, $\xi_{(p,-)}$ is trivialy a wedge in c. Conversely since $\omega_{p,p}$ is universal,every $\left(P\times C\right)$ -indexed family which is natural in $c$ for each $p$ is such a composite, for a unique family $\varrho$ Now $\varrho$ or $\xi$ is extranatural in $p$ (the latter for some $c$ )if and only if the corresponding square below 
$$
\begin{array}{r l r l r}{\overbrace{\vphantom{\int_{c}^{e}}\ensuremath{\sum_{c}}}^{x\to\ensuremath{\ell}_{p}}}&{\underset{c}{\overbrace{\vphantom{\int_{c}^{e}}}^{S(p,p,c,c)}}}&{\qquad}&{\overbrace{\vphantom{\int_{c}^{e}}\ensuremath{\sum_{c}}}^{x\to\ensuremath{\ell}_{p,c}}}&{S(p,p,c,c)}\ {\underset{c}{\overbrace{\vphantom{\int_{c}^{e}}}^{E(p,s,c,c)}}}&{\left\downarrow\ensuremath{\sum_{c}}^{\ensuremath{\Sigma_{\ell}}(p,s,c,c)}\right.}&{}&{\left.\left\downarrow_{q,c}\right.}&{\left\downarrow_{p,c,c}\right)}\ {\int_{c}^{S(q,q,c,c)}\underset{c}{\longrightarrow}\int_{c}^{I\to\ensuremath{\int_{c}}}S(p,q,c,c),}&{}&{\left.S(q,q,c,c)\frac{\ensuremath{\Sigma_{\ell}}}{S(s,q,c,c)}\right.}&{S(p,q,c,c)}\end{array}
$$
